title: About
text:
Hi my name is Emmanuel Yeboah, I currently attending McKinney Boyd High School (Go Broncos!) I am interested in Computer Science, modern technological devices (such as the Google Pixel, self driving taxis, and etc) oh! and I am also interested in science exploration of space, seas, and strange yet fascinating organisms all around earth.


Fuel Efficiency and Weight, this project shows a plot describing the relationship between the weight of cars and how fuel they use (MPG)




To analysis the usage of gas
To analysis the efficiency of gas of cars
To to see how the weight of cars effect fuel usage

Well on most known cars ;)

Number of weights are as follows:


one pound
two pounds
four pounds
five pounds

“This is data science”
~Preceptor
[Kane’s Free Data Science Bootcamp(https://bootcamp.davidkane.info)]

title: first-website
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(ggthemes)





mtcars |> select(mpg, wt) |>
ggplot(aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) + 
geom_point() + 
geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula =  y ~ x, se = FALSE) +
theme_clean() +
labs(title = "Fuel Effciency and Weight",
subtitle = "Heavier cars are less fuel efficient",
y = "MPG",
x = "Weight(1000s of lbs)",
caption = "Henderson and Velieman (1981)")

title: Sources
text: An overview of sources used in my project. These are my sources. Here are some challenges. Quarto websites are awesome.

title: Source 1
text:
Lovelace (1842) is an interesting reference.




References

Lovelace, Augusta Ada. 1842. “Sketch of the Analytical Engine Invented by Charles Babbage, by LF Menabrea, Officer of the Military Engineers, with Notes Upon the Memoir by the Translator.” Taylor’s Scientific Memoirs 3: 666–731.
